> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1144_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): i forgot fuck america and their stupid elementary uneducated languagebetter?

Think of it like this: The fundamental building block of English is the Subject(s)->Verb->Object(s)

There is only one verb in each block. There can be more than one adverb, or verb description, but not more than one verb.

Each of these blocks must be separated with a conjoining word, such as "and", "because", "for", "while", and so on. 

Good english makes precise claims or questions about something doing an action to something else.

Take your english for example. The proper way of writing that would be:

I forgot, fuck America and their stupid language. It is elementary and reveals their lack of education.

You need commas to separate the different subject->verb blocks. Also, educated is a verb and you can't have two verbs in one block.

I don't think block is the scholastically correct word for it but the principle is correct nonetheless.

Evolution is a theory. It's a likely theory but it shouldn't held as dogma. Anyone who tells you otherwise is trying to sell you something.
That being said, who cares how you identify? I know I care more that you make your decisions based on reality and not your imagination alone. 
What I believe is that this metric is better than one that is arbitrary and imaginary.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1374_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Just like gravity is a theory. For a pretentious prick, your vocabulary is lacking.

Gravity and evolution are both theories that attempt to explain physical phenomena. I don't deny the physical phenomena but the accuracy of any interpretation, or theory, can be good or bad. Based on what I know about both phenomena, both theories adequately describe the resulting phenomena. They don't, however, describe all of the functions by which they operate. Further, quantum theory is wholly inadequate while dna evidence explains quite a lot, comparatively.
I find it quite interesting that you use a less understood field of knowledge to prove a better understood one.

One definition of an empire is that it is a state that causes regime change at other regions, with any means, including military means, and has satellite state, protectorates. Have You heard of U.S. troops permanently stationed in Germany and Japan and South-Korea and Poland and Italy and Africa and .... That is how the protectorate game is played. [...]

An empire is a monarchy of hegemonic military power.
The US is not a monarchy, we are a republic.
Speaking of Rome, the Roman REPUBLIC conquered the western world, not the empire.
Empire is mainly not a description of competency but ownership. An country is not an empire without a king, or rather, emperor.

Furthermore, we keep armies around the world because nations want us to for their protection. We spend billions to protect NATO. We don't tax our allies and we don't really control their foreign policy short of not declaring wars against other NATO members. If they wanted out of NATO they could do so immediately and start funding their OWN defense. Your underhanded allegation that our cooperation with NATO makes us as tyrannical as the PRC or the USSR is spurious, false and downright insulting.

Power alone does not tyranny make, but the misuse of such power does. The US has gotten it's power by fighting tyranny, not by extorting it's allies. I say again, our allies CHOOSE to accept our protection. If they didn't, they wouldn't have it. With war in Ukraine, however, it appears that the Russian menace has not yet passed, thus, NATO endures.
